titlestmt.titleproper: A Finding Aid to the Tony Vevers Papers, 1947-2008, bulk 1960-1999, in the Archives of American Art AAA.vevetony
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Harriet E. Shapiro

note.p: This finding aid is associated with a MARC collection-level record. 363703

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2015-10-20T15:40-0400

did.abstract: The papers of painter and art historian Tony Vevers measure 3.4 linear feet and date from 1947 to 2008, with the bulk of materials dating from 1960 to 1999. The collection concerns his career as a painter and teacher and his research and writings about the history of art in Provincetown, Massachusetts. Found within the papers are correspondence, writings, subject files, printed material, and photographs.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The papers were donated to the Archives of American Art in 2013 by Elspeth Halvorsen-Vevers the widow of Vevers.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Also found in the Archives of American Arts are two oral history interviews with Tony Vevers, one conducted by Dorothy Seckler 1965 September 9, the second conducted by Robert F. Brown in 1998 July 9 and August 25.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: The collection was processed and a finding aid prepared in 2014 by Harriet E. Shapiro.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in 7 series:

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: The Tony Vevers papers are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Use of original materials requires an appointment.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Painter and art historian, Tony Vevers (1926-2008) and his artist wife Elspeth Halvorsen (b. 1929) lived and worked in Provincetown, Massachusetts, as year-round or summer residents from 1955 to 2006. From 1964 to 1988, Vevers taught art and art history at Purdue University in Indiana. An active participant in the Provincetown art community, he was also an historian of the Provincetown art scene.

Vevers was born in London, England and immigrated to the United States in 1940, graduating from the Hotchkiss School in Lakeville, Connecticut and Yale University. Following college he studied in Florence, Italy, and with Hans Hofmann in New York City, where he met his wife Elspeth Halvorsen. The couple had two daughters, one of whom, Tabitha is also an artist.

Vevers, active in the Abstract Expressionist movement, had several one-man exhibitions and participated in over one hundred group exhibitions. His works are in the Hirshhorn Museum in Washington, DC, the Delgardo Museum in New Orleans and many universities, corporate, and private collections in the United States and abroad.
Tony Vevers died in Chatham, Massachusetts on March 2, 2008 following complications from pneumonia.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Tony Vevers papers, 1947-2008, bulk 1960-1999. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The papers of painter and art historian Tony Vevers measure 3.4 linear feet and date from 1947 to 2008, with the bulk of materials dating from 1960 to 1999. The collection concerns his career as a painter and teacher and his research and writings about the history of art in Provincetown, Massachusetts. Found within the papers are correspondence, writings, subject files, printed material, and photographs.

Among the biographical materials are résumés, a personal statement, the transcript of Tabitha Vevers's 1986 "Conversation with My Father," and applications for grants to study Provincetown artists and the history of the Provincetown art community from the 1920s to the 1950s. Personal and professional includes some letters to his wife Elspeth.

The collection as a whole—and especially Vevers's writings and subject files–focuses on the Provincetown art community, its history and significance. Vevers's writings include many lectures prepared for classes he taught at Purdue University and the Provincetown Art Association and Museum, catalog essays, and notes. There are notes and research materials about artists Houghton Cranford Smith, E. Ambrose Webster, Edwin Dickinson, and Lucy and William L'Engle, and subject files about the Provincetown Art Association and Museum, Long Point Gallery, and other galleries in the area, as well as a file of Provincetown-related obituaries and eulogies for Hans Hofmann, Robert Motherwell, and Jack Tworkov, with Vevers's eulogies for Tworkov and Myron Stout.

Printed materials consist mainly of clippings, exhibition catalogs and announcements relating to Vevers and his art interests. Artwork consists of a small print and watercolor, probably by Vevers, as well as a pen-and-ink portrait by an unidentified artist.

Photographs are mainly of artwork by Vevers. The two images of Vevers show him as a young boy and in 1984 at work in his studio. There are several photographs of exhibition installations at the Sun Gallery in Provincetown, 1958-1959, identified artists are: Yvonne Andersen, Dominic Falcone, Red Grooms, Taro and Gwen Yamamoto.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Biographical material includes a personal essay by Vevers and his résumé. Two grant applications request funding to study Provincetown's art and artists of the 1920s-1940s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, both personal and professional, consists mostly of incoming letters, some addressed to Vevers’s wife Elspeth Halvorsen. Also included are copies of letters neither written nor received by Vevers, including two letters concerning John P. Sedgewick, Jr.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writings by Vevers include catalog essays, essays, lectures, art history course materials and notes concerning art history and criticism. Many writings relate to Vevers's research on interest in art and the artists and art ofin Provincetown. Lectures and notes prepared for classes at Purdue University and the Provincetown Art Association and Museum reflect his work as a teacher; the course materials were added to and enriched over time. Also included is a Writings by others are a thesis by John P. Sedgewick, Jr. and a the draft of an art history text book by an identified author. of unclear authorship.

did.unittitle: Teaching Notes and Materials, Provincetown Art Association
Teaching Notes and Research, "Art Since 1945," A&D 384, Purdue University
Teaching Notes and Research, Purdue University
Art History Textbook, Manuscript and Notes
"A History of the Reputation of the Duke of Marlborough," by John P. Sedgewick, Jr.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Subject files containing correspondence, printed materials, and notes and writings reflect Vevers' activities and interests. Many files concern Provincetown artists, history, galleries, and exhibitions.

did.unittitle: The Development of Provincetown's Art Colony
"Provincetown Prospects, the Work of Hans Hofmann and His Students" (1994)
"Tony Vevers: A Retrospective of 35 Years Work," Greater Lafayette Art Museum and Provincetown Art Association and Museum (1986)
Vevers Family Exhibitions (Elspeth Halvorsen, Tabitha Vevers, Tony Vevers)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Printed materials include exhibition catalogs, announcements, and clippings noting Vevers and his work. Other clippings and catalogs relate to Vevers's art interests; some may relate to teaching and contemplated writings.

did.unittitle: Exhibition Catalogs, Provincetown Art Association and Museum
Exhibition Catalogs and Announcements, Tony Vevers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Artwork consists of a small watercolor and a print probably by Vevers, as well as a pen-and-ink portrait of a male by an unidentified artist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Included are photographs of works of art by Vevers; photographs of the Sun Gallery in Provincetown including an exterior view of the gallery, exhibition installations, and gallery artists. Installations include: "Children's Art" (1955), "City Show" (1958), Red Grooms (1958), Alex Katz (1958), and "Carnival Show" (1959). Artists shown are: Yvonne Andersen, Dominic Falcone, Red Grooms, Taro and Gwen Yamamoto. Photographs of Vevers show him as a young boy (digital print) and at work in his studio.
